reviewText:
I really shouldn't reccomend this game. After all, it suffers from:
- Very poor handling of the engine it chose.
- Wildly inconsistent framerate.
- Shaky and clunky control scheme.
- Animations that are, quite frankly, ♥♥♥♥ poor.
- Very, very few customization options for your island when it's all said and done.
- Not to be harsh, but art deriction that has little to no interest in creating a unique style or being even pleasant to look at. Although that is hugely subjective.

However, I'm going against my better judgement.
- Firstly, it's free. The final game won't be, but we'll cross that bridge when we come to it.
- Secondly, it's a free creative outlet. You don't see these specific types of level editors everywhere, unless you want to learn how to program. It may be bare-bones, but considering the market isn't exactly brimming with 3D explorative level editors, I'll reluctantly give it a pass.
- And the most important. Even though the final game (If I had to take an educated guess) will probably not be worth buying, it's a cool experiment. What's even cooler is being part of the experiment. Making levels that could be in a fully-partly functional retail game is kind of exhilierating. Especially seeing what other members of the community came up with. Though my levels are sure as hell not going to be featured in the final product, I still feel like I'm apart of something.

So if you're cheap and want a small-scale way to express some creativity (or just want to see what other people came up with) give this game a try. After all, all you have to lose is time.

reviewText: It's not very often you see something like a level editor being made available as a free download; In the current age of gaming, you'd have to shell out a ton of money just to get something like that, and even then it may not contain everything it should have. Seeing a free to use level design tool with workshop support AND the possibility of seeing your creation in the final game is pretty refreshing in my opinion. Sadly, my computer isn't capable of running it due to the fact that it renders the in game graphics, and reducing them does very little. However, that in no way is a fault on the game, but more a fault on me not having the proper hardware. Everything else about this editor as far as I've seen is pretty darn good, and can lead to a lot of possibilities. Just take a look at the Workshop for this editor and you can find pages and pages of beatiful looking environments just itching to be explored. I highly recommend this to any rookie level designer looking for something to start with.

reviewText:
I'd like to explain how great this is with a little scenario.

My first island took 5 hours to making my first island and when I had finished I uploaded it and closed the tool. Turns out it was now 2 o'clock in the morning...and I still wanted to make another!

If you want to contribute to a great game, with a really fun tool that will eat up your life then download this, it's free, it's fun and it's bloody fantastic!

Do I recommend this? Absolutely!

reviewText:
Create badass floating island worlds with a toysRus version of zbrush, materials, dozens of models. Then upload and maybe it goes into Worlds Adrift, the Game™.

Some perf issues even on my moderately beastly machine.

I'd like some more standard editing tools as well. Duplicate, additional axes on the gizmos. The bases are covered, just want more advanced. I love that everything is painted on using brushes, and can then be edited individually. It supports the organic feel of the world.

The tech behind this game looks terrific (improbable.io). Bossa is sick. The use of Steam Workshop is great. This is a great opportunity for building content in a game, and if you don't care about that it's zen-like experience if you just want to chill and paint islands in the sky.

Why can't Unreal and Unity come with Zen music?

reviewText:
The Worlds Adrift Island Creator has it's ups and downs, and yes it is still in a very experimental stage.

Do I think it should have been released in it's current state? Personally, yes. I feel like it gives us as a community a good chance to experiment with the mechanics of the game and get a feel for what's to come.

Is the client still very unfinished? Yes, there are still bugs and lots of things to be improved upon, but those are things that you will always have with clients similar to this one. Like all other beta/alpha games, the client has left much to be desired, but at the same time has given us a chance to have fun and learn.

With all of the feedback that will come from this, I feel like Bossa will be able to really improve the mechanics of the game based on what the community feels is necessary. After all, the people that will be playing the game should be the people that have a voice and suggestion as to what things should be added/removed from the game, right?

Overall I like that Bossa has given us this opportunity, a learning experience, and I look forward to seeing where things go in the near future.

reviewText: Uhm... No. Not in its current state. It needs to be optimized. It needs improvement all around. Tools are clunky, unresponsive or over-responsive. Where is the water? Performance is terrible considering the poor level of detail you can get from this. Graphics are indeed lackluster. For this kind of performance hit, I'd expect to see something decent on my screen. Can't recommend this at the present. To make things worse, these guys are essentially releasing sub-par tools and asking the community to do the heavy lifting. If you want me to do any heavy lifting, you need to give me something worthy of the effort. I've used too many world-builders, terrain generators, and similar tools to find this program remotely acceptable. I want waterfalls pouring off the sides of my island. I want sun-shafts filtering through the trees. I want something more. Too quick to rush something into release. Same problem a lot of devs have it seems these days.

reviewText: This is a Game" that lets you create content for another game that will be released later and if you're one of the people who's content is selected you'll get to see it in the upcoming game. Okay? Got that? Are you Sure? Because I don't think you do.\n\nModding is one thing. After a game comes out
date: you'll see people happily plugging away at making mods for games they like. Fine. Dandy. This isn't that.\n\nYou are literally doing the work of an employee of this company
recommended: for free. Get it? You're not playing a game
hoursPlayed: you're working. This is stuff that normal game developers hire people to do. This whole thing is a farce designed to net the company free content to flesh out another product. This would be the same as Bethesda releasing the modding tools for the next Elder Scrolls game before the game was out
voteText: then taking the best mods and incorporating them into the game

reviewText:
After finally getting the game to work, I still do not recommend it and here is why: Terrain Manipulation, the brushes are just awful, I cannot stand them I will never understand how these guys are creating these super smooth perfect islands, I just cannot get the brushes to do ANYTHING I want, it just conforms to this random hidious jagged terrain that still looks like ♥♥♥♥ after using the smoothing tool.

Another reason why I cannot stand this, there is no smoothing brush, WHY?! the smoothing tool really is kind of poor, I would REALLY like to see a smoothing brush. mass placement in my opinion should just be limited to ONE obj at a time, because if you forget to deselect one single thing and hit the generation button you could end up with a massive amount of unwanted objects suddenly placed.

Overall I just do not like the way the brushes work, the texturing tool takes some time to get used to but it is nice. I still however do not and will not recommend this tool.

reviewText:
I gotta say if you're into world building and creating levels and what not, whether it be something simple like Project Spark on xbox or even a game engine, then this is a nice little treat to try out. The aesthetic of the game has a nice simple but pleasing look to it. The assets, things like rocks or trees, are well modeled and easy to work with and the enviroment tools are simple and easy to use for pretty much anyone. The game also has a very nice relaxing background music to it that im liking.
Although there are some flaws/tweaks that I would like to see fixed or more refined.

Firstly is the UI. While it is easy to get used too, it would be nice to move the object editor to the asset pool options as a way to easily edit whatever you're going use before you put it down.
Secondly is to have some better optimization added. While I was suprised to get this working at the level I did, seeing more options in the settings would be much apprectiated.
Thirldy is another settings options pertaining to the controls. Currently there is no option to either rebind your movement keys and as far as im aware there also wasn't even a way to see what keys do what (Please correct me if im wrong on this).
And lastly, mostly personal options, but being able to customize your character a bit would be nice, as well as adding some more textures for the terrain, and also maybe particle effects like fire, water, or energy obs and what not.

All in all Worlds Adrift is definitly something to try out since it is currenlty free and system requirements are pretty low, so if this might seem to tickle your fancy then give it a download!
